newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.African rand/bonds closing report.
newsitem.headline: S.African rand/bonds closing report.

text.p: The rand's attempt to breach the psychological 4.50 level against the dollar barrier was thwarted on Wednesday by local importers buying dollars at their cheapest level in three weeks.
At the finish, the rand was quoted 4.5050/5100 against the dollar from 4.5190/5240 on Tuesday after touching 4.4950 in the pre-opening trade -- its best level since August 8.
Dealers said the currency was helped at the start of the day by reports that Taiwan planned to build a petrochemical plant valued at more than $3 billion in South Africa.
"We had a fairly bullish start with some dollar selling out of London," a dealer said. "But after breaking below 4.50, we saw a lot of importer demand which took it back up again."
After the initial move below key support at the 4.5160/80 level, dealers said resistance had been set at around 4.5150 and the rand traded in a narrow range for the rest of the day.
"We saw some good two-way flows today...good importer demand and some offshore buying below 4.50 and exporters and offshore selling around 4.5150," one trader said.
Another trader said there had been talk that the Reserve Bank had also helped the rand strengthen on the day by offering dollars through the smaller banks.
Dealers said that in the short-term, the 4.50 level would remain a target, but a breach of that level could herald a rand of 4.48 to the dollar and 4.45 beyond that.
The liquidation of long dollar positions over the last week appeared to be coming to a halt, although a trader said "dribs and drabs" were still helping the currency.
Against the crosses, the rand was trading at 7.0226/0349 on sterling from 6.9984/7.0084 on Tuesday and at 0.3271/3277 marks from 0.3263/3268 marks previously.

Bond yields were helped lower at the opening by the stronger rand, but a lack of significant buying as well as some profit taking resulted in the key R150 retracing from its intraday low of 15.41 percent.
Dealers said volumes on the day had been thin with little or no institutional or foreign interest.
Talk late in the day that July money supply data would "not be as bad as expected" helped the R150 revisit its intraday low shortly after the official close.

The Reserve Bank said money supply growth rose 14.69 percent in July -- well below a Reuters consensus forecast of 16.2 percent. Private sector credit extension grew 18.50 percent compared with a revised 18.65 percent in June.
In late trade, the R150 moved lower to test the 15.40 area and was quoted at 15.36 percent at 1530 GMT from 15.48 percent on Tuesday.
Bond Exchange figures showed foreigners were net sellers of 101.45 million rand of South African bonds on Tuesday after buying 41.19 million rand on Monday.

On the money market, three-month NCDs eased to between 16.55 and 16.70 percent from between 16.60 and 16.75 percent on Tuesday and from 16.65 and 16.75 percent on Monday, while 90-day BAs were lower at between 16.00 and 16.10 percent from 16.05 to 16.20 percent previously.
The Reserve Bank said the money market shortage eased to 8.705 billion rand on Tuesday from 8.779 billion rand on Monday.
